Award.AwardTitle: Structure, Dynamics and Energetics of Protein Unfolded States

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The native state of a protein is the structure that is most thermodynamically stable and is normally the biologically active form. Protein folding begins from a less structured collection of states, commonly known as the denatured state ensemble (DSE). The DSE is considerably harder to study than the native state owing to its dynamic and flexible nature, and to the fact that the vast majority of protein molecules populate the native state under normal conditions. Nevertheless, understanding the DSE is fundamentally important for understanding of protein folding and stability. The stability of a protein is dictated by the free energy difference between the native state and the DSE, thus any changes in solution conditions or mutations that alter the DSE can alter stability and folding. The DSE is the reference state for stability measurements; much of our quantitative understanding of the specific interactions involved in stabilizing the native state of proteins is derived from experiments that make implicit assumptions about the DSE. In addition, the DSE can be the starting state for nonproductive protein aggregation, a process that impacts biotechnology and biology. This project is directed at fundamental studies of protein folding, focusing on the role of the DSE. A deeper understanding of the properties of the DSE and the role that the DSE plays in folding is required for a complete description of protein folding and aggregation. The DSE can be populated under harsh, non-physiological conditions, but progress requires characterization of the DSE under conditions that are relevant for folding and aggregation, i.e., under conditions where the native state is stable. Comparative experimental studies of a set of three representative model proteins will be carried out under physiologically relevant designed conditions. The experimental work will be closely integrated with efforts by theoretical collaborators.

A range of educational and outreach activities are planned. An 'adopt a lab' program has been initiated as part of the first year undergraduate honors lab class and will be further developed. Interactions with Stony Brook University?s project WISE (Women in Science and Engineering) program will be established to provide support and encouragement to undergraduate women who are interested in science and engineering. Laboratory exercises will also be designed to interface with project WISE. Graduate and undergraduate training and mentoring are key components of the project. Outreach activities include visits and seminars at undergraduate institutions, as well as collaborations with researchers at primarily undergraduate institutions. The research goals of the project aim to answer fundamental questions in protein folding. As part of the work, new tools and methodologies will also be developed which can be applied to a range of problems in protein structure and dynamics beyond the area of protein folding.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this NSF funded research was to define the properties of unfolded states of proteins and to test certain theories of their behavior and to study key events in the protein folding process. Proteins normally need to self-assemble into their folded state, often called the native state, to be functional. The unfolded state is the starting state for folding, both in the test tube and in the cell. Understanding the interactions which occur in protein unfolded states and elucidating the basis towards structure in the unfolded state are important because they directly impact the folding process and because the unfolded state can be the starting point for protein mis-folding and aggregation. Protein mis-folding and aggregation underpin a range of devastating human disorders and are also a major issue in the biotechnology and bio-pharmaceutical industries. However, an atomic-level description of unfolded states under conditions relevant for protein function has remained elusive. Challenges arise from the pronounced structural heterogeneity of the unfolded state and because of the very low population of unfolded states under native conditions. We have combined a series of time-resolved biophysical experiments with computer simulations simulations and polymer theory to obtain a high-resolution description of unfolded state under native conditions.

We used our knowledge of protein unfolded state to developed a general method for increasing the stability of globular proteins by rationally altering the proteins of the unfolded state,

We also used high pressure to gain insight into protein folding transition states. Unfolded proteins occupy a smaller volume than a folded protein. At first glance this may seem counter-intuitive; the effect arises because folded proteins contain small cavities which are too small for a water molecule to fit into and this leads to empty space.  In contrast water molecules can pack tightly around an unfolded protein and the total volume of the system (water plus protein) is less. Thus, protein folding is notably slower at high pressure.  We exploited this effect to study protein folding in real time with unprecedented resolution. The work provided fundamental insight into protein folding. Our high pressure studies combined with our study of the effects of mutations on protein folding is consistent with a view whereby proteins fold by arranging their backbone into approximately the correct structure and then latter consolidate side-chain side-chain interactions.

As part of our NSF supported research we developed new, site specific, fluorescence probes of protein structure and demonstrated how these can be used to follow protein folding and monitor protein protein interactions. The advantages of the new methods are that they provide  specific probes of local structure in a non-perturbing manner.

This project provided training in fundamental biophysics and biochemistry to 5 PhD students and 1 undergraduate student.
